EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Background Data

In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68) promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at their Traverse City, Michigan facility.  Hillshire Brands -Traverse City operations include the processing of frozen baked and unbaked pies and desert cups for public consumption. Hillshire Brands -Traverse City has been in operation at this facility for over 40 years providing quality products and over 500 jobs to the local community.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Hillshire Brands -Traverse City is committed to protecting the health of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment; therefore it is Hillshire Brands -Traverse City, MI policy to manage a safe and healthy workplace, protect the environment, and maintain compliance with safety, health, and environmental regulations: 40 CFR 68 as well as Occupational Safety and Health Organization (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations promulgated as Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 1910, Section 119 (29 CFR 1910.119), and OSHAA¿s Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations (29 CFR 1910.120).

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

Hillshire Brands -Traverse City, MI is required to maintain low temperatures in the food processing areas of the plant that are within standards required to ensure quality in the final products.  Hillshire Brands -Traverse City, MI uses anhydrous ammonia (a 112(r) regulated substance) as a refrigerant to maintain the facility within the required range of operating temperatures.  Anhydrous ammonia is an industry-standard refrigerant, used in systems consisting of receivers, compressors, evaporators, condensers, and piping in an engineered closed loop system.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

Anhydrous Ammoni

a

The ammonia refrigeration system is designed and constructed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-1992 Standards for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems.  To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has implemented several precautionary measures, such as process/equipment controls, standard operating procedures, preventative maintenance programs, employee training and audit programs.  

Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI maintains a "no odor" policy.  The "no odor" policy instructs employees that detect an ammonia odor to call the Refrigeration Maintenance staff and the staff must respond immediately to the call to address the situation.

Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has implemented and is in compliance with OSHA's PSM regulations and as such, has evaluated and engineered for anhydrous ammonia releases.   Some of the controls installed to prevent catastrophic releases of ammonia are process equipment (vents, pressure relief valves, backup pumps, and manual shutoffs) and automated controls (automatic shut-offs, ammonia leak detection system, and electrical distribution system grounding).  In addition, Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has trained approximately 25 personnel to respond to potential ammonia releases (HazMat response team).

Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has developed Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for all employees and contractors that have contact with the ammonia refrigeration system that incorporate safety measures into the procedures.  These safety procedures were developed by refrigeration system operators and are reviewed on an annual basis by means of a SOP review session.  Process safety information for the refrigeration system is reviewed during these annual meetings as well.  Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI encourages employee participation in development of the control measures used at the plant by means of

the annual procedures review.  Any changes to the operating procedures are communicated to affected employees following written management of change procedures established by Hillshire Brands -Traverse City, MI.

Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI understands that maintaining the refrigeration system in good working order is essential to preventing accidental releases; therefore Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has implemented a Preventative Maintenance (PM) program.  The Preventative Maintenance program is scheduled, documented and managed to ensure that regular maintenance occurs on the refrigeration system.  Also, to ensure the mechanical integrity of critical refrigeration system components, auditing is conducted every 5 years by a certified refrigeration contractor.

To ensure that Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI control measures are effective in maintaining the safe operation of the plant, regularly scheduled audits are performed on the ammonia refrigeration system:

In accordance with the PSM program, Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI conducts detailed PSM compliance audits every three years that incorporates review of process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training programs, system mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-start up review procedures, compliance audit procedures, incident investigation procedures, employee participation programs, hot work permit procedures, and contractor safety procedures.

In addition, Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI is subject to auditing by the local fire department, OSHA, and the Environmental Protection Agency.

Five-Year Accident History

Over the last five years, Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has not experienced an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia causing any on-site death, injury or significant property damage, or known off-site death, injury, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.

Emergency

Response Program

Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has developed a comprehensive emergency response program designed to protect both employees and the community in the event of a release.  This program is fully described in a document entitled EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN (ERP) in order to facilitate response efforts in the event of off-site releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Included in the Response Plan are measures to be taken internally by Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI as well as measures to be taken by off-site response agencies.

Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has trained approximately 25 on-site personnel to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances.  These personnel are trained in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120, OSHA's Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations according to their duties and function.  These personnel receive initial training and annual update training thereafter. Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI stages mock release incidents at least annually to test the skills of the HazMat team, determine the team's readiness, and identify areas of improvement.

To assure that the local governmental response agencies are familiar with Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI emergency response procedures, Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI has submitted copies of the ERP for review and approval by the local agencies.  The following local agencies have participated Mock release events to gain knowledge and understanding of the Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI ERP:

Grand Traverse Metro Fire Department

To pre-plan for an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site effects, Hillshire Brands - Traverse City, MI ERP includes procedures/equipment to mitigate the release, procedures to inform local response agencies, evacuation procedures, and procedures for public communication.

In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site effects, the general public will be warned by the Local Emergency Planning

Committee (LEPC) according to the facility's off-site plan which is updated on an annual basis by the LEPC.  Any significant changes to the ERP will be communicated to the agencies listed above.

Continuous Efforts to Improve Safety

No changes to the ammonia refrigeration process are planned at this time.   However, the process will be subjected to regular process hazard analyses reviews for the purpose of identifying and implementing potential improvements. Facility and Corporate personnel will also periodically review all potential opportunities to improve the safety of our personnel, the surrounding community, and the ammonia refrigeration process.
